subfields.name: Perception and Computer Vision
keyProblems: Robustness to noise and sensor limitations
applications: Autonomous Vehicles: Lane keeping, pedestrian detection, traffic sign recognition.
Robotics: Object manipulation, navigation, human-robot collaboration (e.g., picking items in a warehouse, surgical robots).
Medical Imaging: Disease diagnosis (e.g., tumor detection in X-rays), surgical guidance.
Surveillance and Security: Facial recognition, anomaly detection.
Augmented Reality/Virtual Reality: Environment mapping, object tracking.
timeline: 1960s: Early efforts in AI to interpret images (e.g., MIT Summer Vision Project).
1970s-1980s: Development of foundational algorithms for edge detection (Marr-Hildreth, Canny), corner detection (Harris), and basic stereo vision.
1990s: Emergence of feature-based approaches (SIFT, SURF), increased focus on real-time systems.
2000s: Rise of machine learning for classification tasks (Support Vector Machines, boosting).
2012: AlexNet's breakthrough in ImageNet Large Scale Visual Recognition Challenge (ILSVRC), signaling the deep learning revolution.
2010s-Present: Dominance of deep learning for almost all vision tasks, rapid advancements in real-time performance and accuracy.

subfields.name: Image Processing Fundamentals
keyProblems: Noise reduction without losing important details
Handling different image formats and compressions
applications: Pre-processing for Computer Vision: Noise removal, contrast normalization.
Medical Imaging: Enhancing X-rays, MRI scans.
Quality Control: Detecting defects in manufacturing.
timeline: 1960s: First digital image processing on computers (e.g., for space exploration images).
1970s: Development of fundamental filters and operations.
1980s-1990s: Proliferation of software libraries and specialized hardware.
Present: Integration with deep learning for advanced image synthesis and manipulation.
advancements: Integration of deep learning for super-resolution and denoising.

literature.name: Digital Image Processing by Gonzalez & Woods

subfields.name: Feature Extraction and Description
coreConcepts: Descriptors (histograms of gradients, local binary patterns)
keyProblems: Robustness to illumination, viewpoint changes, and noise
Computational cost of extraction and matching
applications: Object Tracking: Following objects in video.
Image Retrieval: Finding similar images in databases.
Localization: Identifying a robot's position based on visual landmarks.
Augmented Reality: Overlaying digital content onto the real world.
timeline: 1999: Introduction of SIFT, a breakthrough in robust feature description.
2006: SURF (Speeded Up Robust Features) as a faster alternative to SIFT.
2011: ORB (Oriented FAST and Rotated BRIEF) for real-time applications.
2010s-Present: Development of learning-based feature descriptors (e.g., L2-Net, SuperPoint) using deep neural networks.
advancements: Development of highly discriminative and compact descriptors.
Real-time performance for feature extraction and matching.
Learning-based methods surpassing traditional handcrafted features.

literature.name: Distinctive image features from scale-invariant keypoints by Lowe
SURF: Speeded Up Robust Features by Bay, Tuytelaars, & Van Gool
ORB: an efficient alternative to SIFT or SURF by Rublee et al.

subfields.name: Object Detection and Recognition
coreConcepts: Localization (identifying *where* an object is, via bounding box)
Instance Segmentation (pixel-level classification for individual instances)
keyProblems: Handling occlusions and variations in pose
Domain adaptation (transferring models to new environments)
Computational resources for training and inference
applications: Autonomous Driving: Detecting vehicles, pedestrians, traffic lights.
Robotics: Picking and placing objects, grasping, human-robot interaction.
Medical Imaging: Detecting anomalies or organs.
timeline: Pre-2012: Handcrafted features + classifiers (e.g., Viola-Jones for face detection).
2012: AlexNet's success in ImageNet sparks interest in CNNs for recognition.
2014: R-CNN introduces region proposals with CNNs for object detection.
2015: Faster R-CNN integrates region proposal network, making it end-to-end. YOLO and SSD introduced for real-time single-shot detection.
2017: Mask R-CNN extends to instance segmentation.
2018-Present: Continued improvements in accuracy and speed, emergence of transformer-based models (e.g., DETR).
advancements: End-to-end trainable deep learning models for detection and segmentation.
Significant improvements in accuracy and speed (real-time applications).
Development of robust models for diverse environments and object scales.
Transfer learning and pre-trained models for faster development.

literature.name: Rich feature hierarchies for accurate object detection and semantic segmentation by Girshick et al. (R-CNN)
Faster R-CNN: Towards real-time object detection with region proposal networks by Ren et al.
You Only Look Once: Unified, Real-Time Object Detection by Redmon et al. (YOLO)
Mask R-CNN by He et al.

subfields.name: 3D Reconstruction and Point Cloud Processing
coreConcepts: Depth sensing (Stereo Vision, Structured Light, Time-of-Flight)
SLAM (Simultaneous Localization and Mapping) - often uses 3D data
keyProblems: Noise and sparsity in point cloud data
Computational cost of processing large 3D datasets
Handling dynamic environments and moving objects
applications: Robotics: Environment mapping, object manipulation, grasping in 3D.
Autonomous Vehicles: Creating high-definition maps, obstacle detection.
Virtual/Augmented Reality: Building 3D models of real-world scenes.
Architecture and Construction: Building Information Modeling (BIM), progress monitoring.
Cultural Heritage Preservation: Digitizing historical artifacts.
Industrial Inspection: Quality control, defect detection on surfaces.
timeline: 1980s-1990s: Early work on stereo vision and photometric stereo.
2000s: Development of Structure from Motion (SfM) for reconstructing 3D scenes from uncalibrated images. Multi-View Stereo (MVS) algorithms.
2010: Release of Microsoft Kinect, democratizing RGB-D sensing and sparking research in real-time dense 3D reconstruction (e.g., KinectFusion).
2010s-Present: Advancements in LiDAR technology, integration of deep learning for semantic segmentation and feature extraction on point clouds.
advancements: Robust algorithms for registering large and noisy point clouds.
Deep learning on point clouds (e.g., PointNet, PointNet++).

literature.name: Computer Vision: Algorithms and Applications by Szeliski
KinectFusion: Real-time dense surface reconstruction and tracking by Newcombe et al.
PointNet: Deep Learning on Point Sets for 3D Classification and Segmentation by Qi et al.

subfields.name: Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM)
coreConcepts: Mapping (building a representation of the environment)
Data association (matching observations to known landmarks)
State estimation (Kalman Filters, Particle Filters, Optimization-based methods)
applications: Autonomous Vehicles: Self-driving cars need to know where they are and build maps.
Robotics: Mobile robot navigation, domestic robots (e.g., robot vacuums), industrial AGVs.
Augmented Reality: Tracking device pose and mapping the environment for AR overlays.
Indoor Navigation: Mapping and localization for wayfinding.
timeline: 1980s: Initial theoretical formulations of SLAM, often using Kalman filters for small environments.
1990s: Focus on Extended Kalman Filter (EKF) SLAM and early visual SLAM concepts.
2000s: Particle filters (FastSLAM), appearance-based SLAM, and the rise of graph-based optimization methods. PTAM introduces parallel tracking and mapping.
2010: Kinect sensor democratizes RGB-D SLAM (e.g., KinectFusion for dense reconstruction).
2015: ORB-SLAM (Visual SLAM) achieves high accuracy and robustness. Google releases Cartographer (LiDAR-based SLAM).
2010s-Present: Focus on robust, real-time, large-scale SLAM; multi-sensor fusion, semantic SLAM, and learning-based approaches.
advancements: Development of robust, real-time visual SLAM systems (e.g., ORB-SLAM3).
High-accuracy LiDAR-based SLAM for mapping large outdoor environments.
Effective multi-sensor fusion for improved robustness (e.g., VIO).
Loop closure detection leading to globally consistent maps.
Integration of semantic information to create 'intelligent' maps.

literature.name: Simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM): part I the essential fundamentals by Durrant-Whyte & Bailey
Parallel Tracking and Mapping for Small AR Workspaces by Klein & Murray (PTAM)
ORB-SLAM: A Versatile and Accurate Monocular SLAM System by Mur-Artal et al.
LSD-SLAM: Large-Scale Direct Monocular SLAM by Engel et al.

subfields.name: Sensor Fusion
coreConcepts: Multiple sensor modalities (camera, LiDAR, radar, IMU, GPS)
State estimation (Kalman Filters, Extended Kalman Filters, Unscented Kalman Filters, Particle Filters)
keyProblems: Handling different sensor update rates and latencies
Dealing with sensor failures or noise
Optimal weighting of diverse sensor data
applications: Autonomous Vehicles: Combining camera, LiDAR, radar, and GPS for robust perception and localization.
Robotics: Enhancing robot pose estimation, environmental understanding, and object tracking.
Navigation Systems: Combining GPS, IMU, and visual odometry for accurate indoor/outdoor positioning.
Human Activity Recognition: Fusing data from wearable sensors.
Medical Devices: Combining various physiological sensors for better diagnostics.
timeline: 1960s: Introduction of the Kalman Filter, initially for aerospace applications (e.g., Apollo program).
1980s-1990s: Application of Kalman filters to robotics for state estimation (e.g., mobile robot localization).
2000s: Development of more advanced filters (UKF, PF) and increased use in autonomous systems.

2010s-Present: Widespread adoption in autonomous vehicles and advanced robotics due to the availability of diverse and complementary sensors. Focus on robust, real-time, and adaptive fusion techniques.
advancements: Development of robust and efficient non-linear filters.
Learning-based fusion techniques that can adapt to sensor noise and biases.
Graph-optimization approaches for globally consistent state estimation (e.g., GTSAM).
Sophisticated methods for online sensor calibration.

literature.name: An Introduction to the Kalman Filter by Welch & Bishop
Probabilistic Robotics by Thrun, Burgard, & Fox
Multitarget-Multisensor Tracking: Principles and Techniques by Bar-Shalom and Li

advancements: Deep Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) leading to super-human performance in specific tasks.
Real-time object detection models (e.g., YOLO, SSD).
Robust SLAM algorithms for complex environments.
Development of large-scale annotated datasets (e.g., ImageNet, COCO).
Event cameras and neuromorphic vision for high-speed, low-power perception.

literature.name: Vision: A Computational Investigation into the Human Representation and Processing of Visual Information by Marr
A Computational Approach to Edge Detection by Canny
Distinctive image features from scale-invariant keypoints by Lowe (SIFT)
ImageNet Classification with Deep Convolutional Neural Networks by Krizhevsky, Sutskever, & Hinton (AlexNet paper)
CVPR (Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition)
NeurIPS (Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems)
